content.title: Small Saphenous Vein Anatomy
content.description: Detailed anatomy of the small saphenous vein, the superficial vein of the posterior calf that drains into the popliteal vein.
content.definition: The small saphenous vein (SSV) originates from the lateral marginal vein of the foot, passes posterior to the lateral malleolus, ascends the posterior midline of the calf between the heads of the gastrocnemius, and typically terminates at the saphenopopliteal junction (SPJ) by joining the popliteal vein.

course: Origin: Lateral marginal vein of foot
saphenopopliteal_junction: Highly variable location (popliteal fossa to mid-thigh)
May join popliteal vein at various heights
May connect to GSV via Giacomini vein
May drain into deep thigh veins
variability: SPJ absent in 10-20% (drains via Giacomini vein)
important_relations: Sural nerve: Runs closely with SSV below mid-calf

learning_objectives: Trace SSV course from foot to SPJ
Apply preoperative mapping for SSV procedures
clinical_pearls: SPJ location is highly variable - ALWAYS map with ultrasound
Sural nerve injury causes lateral foot numbness
Giacomini vein connects SSV to GSV in thigh
SSV reflux can cause lateral/posterior calf varicosities
Prone positioning may be needed for SSV ablation
